head.title: Arafat Must End Violence In Mideast, Lieberman Says

hedline.hl1: Arafat Must End Violence In Mideast, Lieberman Says

abstract.p: Sen Joseph I Lieberman, at fund-raiser, Los Angeles, lauds Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak as Palestinians' best hope for peace and puts onus for halting Mideast violence on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; Democratic vice presidential candidate is believed to be articulating Clinton administration stand, although Pres Clinton has avoided placing blame; Dick Cheney, Lieberman's Republican counterpart, lauds Barak, campaign appearance, Fulton, Mo; scores Arafat (M)

block.p: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman praised Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel today as the Palestinians' best hope for peace and placed the onus for halting Mideast violence squarely on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.

''The tragedy here, with all respect,'' Mr. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, said at a fund-raiser here, ''is that Chairman Arafat, particularly, has not seized this moment of opportunity to reach across the table and meet Barak to create the kind of understanding that is clearly in the best interests of all the peoples in the region and in the best interests of the United States.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman praised Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel today as the Palestinians' best hope for peace and placed the onus for halting Mideast violence squarely on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.

''The tragedy here, with all respect,'' Mr. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, said at a fund-raiser here, ''is that Chairman Arafat, particularly, has not seized this moment of opportunity to reach across the table and meet Barak to create the kind of understanding that is clearly in the best interests of all the peoples in the region and in the best interests of the United States.

''We in the United States really have to call upon the leadership of the Palestinian community to stop the violence, to stop the unrest, to be leaders,'' Mr. Lieberman said. He was articulating what is believed to be the position of the Clinton administration, although President Clinton, trying to resurrect the Palestinian-Israeli peace talks he has mediated, has carefully avoided saying that one side had more responsibility than the other for ending the bloodshed.

Mr. Lieberman today went far beyond what the president has been willing to say. His remarks, a long, impassioned digression from his usual stump speech, were not planned, catching even his aides off guard.

The senator, who said the Middle East was seeing ''potentially a tragic moment of a lost, historic opportunity,'' praised Mr. Barak as someone who had gone further than any other Israeli leader in making concessions to the Palestinians and trying to forge a permanent peace.

Mr. Lieberman's Republican counterpart, Dick Cheney, also praised Mr. Barak today at a campaign appearance in Fulton, Mo., describing him as a good man he had worked with in the past. But Mr. Cheney was critical of Mr. Arafat, saying, ''Yasir Arafat has not been able to deliver.''

Mr. Cheney spoke at Westminster College, where Winston Churchill first warned in 1946 of an ''iron curtain'' descending over Europe. Mr. Cheney pressed his case for maintaining a strong United States military even though the cold war has ended.
